title: Doesn't it impress you that the term 'human fecal dust' isn't known to scientists and couldn't be found even on the internet? - Quora

response.answer_text: Q: Doesn't it impress you that the term "human fecal dust" isn't known to scientists and couldn't be found even on the internet? A: No. What impresses me, is the distance to which people will go in seeking something to worry about, all the while ignoring the real threats. No matter what microscopic threat “human fecal dust” actually poses, past experience in investigating ‘popular’ health threats assures me that it is extremely likely that that risk is a TINY FRACTION of the risk from smoking,drinking more than 1 drink per day,overeating,failing to exercise, oreating convenience foods.I’m further impressed by how incredibly illiterate even college-educated adults often are, with respect to basic science and statistics, rendering them incapable of making reasonable evaluations of ‘trending’ reports in the media and in Internet social gossip of various environmental, economic, and health worries.  UPDATE: After the comment, below from the original questioner, I decided to check what might have been published about “human fecal dust”. I found two interesting points: Searching Google for “human fecal dust”[1] I discovered that Quora is the #1 source for ‘information’ on “human fecal dust”!Searching Google Scholar for “human fecal dust”[2] , I discovered that the number of scholarly articles on “human fecal dust” is . . . ZERO! The moment in the drafty church at smokerise Footnotes[1] "human fecal dust" - Google Search[2] Google Scholar

First, no, it doesn't impress me, as it was recently made up, as a scarier, more “sciency", substitute for"fecal contamination “ or “fecal bacteria". Second, yes, it is found on the internet, and not only on Quora. Read the Popular Science article “You Cannot Escape Poop Bacteria". Your entire house, and a good part of the outdoors, have bacteria which are found in feces. Kitchens generally have more even than bathrooms. Your clothes, your books, your walls, are coated in them. If you add in animal fecal bacteria, it's pretty much 100% of surfaces, including under the soil. Nature recycles everything. Fecal matter and dead animals and plants make up what is referred to as “organic matter" in soil. Soil is almost infertile without it, and cannot hold water properly. The vast majority of fecal bacteria are beneficial. You could not digest your food without them. Ever hear of a “poop transplant"? It's where feces from a healthy person are placed inside the intestines of someone who has lost their proper mix of bacteria, and is chronically ill as a result. Approximately 50% of fecal volume is bacteria. That's right. Half of the volume of your poop is bacteria.

It is obvious that the known hygiene measures, as is hand washing etc, are not enough, as now a new microbe source, up to now ignored, is added. Up to now NOT A SINGLE scientific study have ever doubted fecal dust’s existence and its role on microbe dispersion, but however no hygiene measures are imposed or advice is given by Health Institutes, particularly to women to prevent UTI, or any guiding to hospital hygiene managers to reduce HAI and the growing danger of microbe resistant to antibiotics “

Is HFD common? When did you last see a desiccated turd? I suspect the term is known to a few scientists, epidemiologists & hygienists perhaps, but why should a low-temperature physicist, or a forensic econometrist, for instance, ever have heard of it? Scientists are not a single, undifferentiated species. I get the impression that you hate scientists. I may be wrong. Are you a religionist?

I spent a summer in intimate contact with literally tons of human fecal dust. The Milwaukee sewage system markets its waste as a “golf course fertilizer,” Milorganite. (it must be good, it’s organic!). We spread it on the grounds of the Milwaukee Public School (MPS) system. My Pa told me that it is especially fertile due to the brewery waste that was included. Last I heard the performance of the MPS left something to be desired … maybe this explains it!
